title: Parallel Clique Counting and Peeling Algorithms

sections.related work:
Theory. A trivial algorithm can compute all k𝑘k-cliques
in O​(nk)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑘O(n^{k}) work. Using degree-based thresholding enables
clique counting in O​(mk/2)𝑂superscript𝑚𝑘2O(m^{k/2}) work, which is asymptotically
faster for sparse graphs. Chiba and Nishizeki give an
algorithm with improved complexity for sparse graphs,
in which all k𝑘k-cliques can be found in O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2})
work , where α𝛼\alpha is the arboricity of the graph. For arbitrary graphs, the fastest theoretical algorithm uses matrix
multiplication, and counts 3​l3𝑙3l cliques in O​(nl​ω)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑙𝜔O(n^{l\omega}) time
where ω𝜔\omega is the matrix multiplication
exponent . The k𝑘k-clique problem is a
canonical hard problem in the FPT literature, and is known to be
W​[ref]1𝑊delimited-[]1W[ref]1-complete when parametrized by k𝑘k . We
refer the reader to , which surveys
other theoretical algorithms for this problem. Recent work by Dhulipala et al.  studied k𝑘k-clique counting in the parallel batch-dynamic setting. One of their
algorithms calls our arb-count as a
subroutine. Practice. The special case of counting and listing
triangles (k=3𝑘3k=3) has received a huge amount of attention over the
past two decades (e.g., 5   , among many
others). Finocchi et al.  present parallel k𝑘k-clique counting algorithms for MapReduce. Jain and Seshadri 7
provide algorithms for estimating k𝑘k-clique counts. The state-of-the-art
k𝑘k-clique counting and listing algorithm is kClist by Danisch
et al. , which is based on the
Chiba-Nishizeki algorithm, but uses the k𝑘k-core
ordering (which is not parallel) to rank vertices.
It achieves O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work, but
does not have polylogarithmic span due to the ordering
and only parallelizing one or two levels of recursion.
Concurrent with our work, Li et al.  present an ordering heuristic for k𝑘k-clique counting based on graph coloring, which they show improves upon kClist in practice. It would be interesting in the future to study their heuristic applied to our algorithm. Additionally, many algorithms have been designed for finding 4-
and 5-vertex subgraphs
(e.g.,     )
as well as estimating larger subgraph counts
(e.g.,  ), and these algorithms can be
used for counting exact or approximate k𝑘k-clique counting as a special case.
Worst-case optimal join algorithms from the database
literature [ref]1    can also be used
for k𝑘k-clique listing and counting as a special case, and would require
O​(mk/2)𝑂superscript𝑚𝑘2O(m^{k/2}) work. Very recently, Jain and Seshadri 8 present a sequential
and a vertex parallel Pivoter algorithm for counting all cliques in a
graph.
However, their algorithm cannot be used for
k𝑘k-clique listing as they avoid processing all cliques, and requires much
more than O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work in the worst case. Low Out-degree Orientations. A canonical technique in the
graph algorithms literature on clique counting, listing, and related
tasks 0 8  is the
use of a low out-degree orientation. Matula and Beck  show that k𝑘k-core
gives an O​(α)𝑂𝛼O(\alpha) orientation.
However, the problem of computing this ordering is
𝖯𝖯\mathsf{P}-complete , and thus unlikely to have
polylogarithmic span. More recent work in the distributed and
external-memory literature has shown that such orderings can be
efficiently computed in these settings. Barenboim and Elkin give a
distributed algorithm that finds an O​(α)𝑂𝛼O(\alpha)-orientation in O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) rounds . Goodrich and Pszona give a similar
algorithm for external-memory 5. Concurrent with our work,
Besta et al.  present a parallel algorithm for generating
an O​(α)𝑂𝛼O(\alpha)-orientation in O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m) work and O​(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n) span,
which they use for parallel graph coloring. Vertex Peeling and k𝑘k-clique Densest Subgraph. An
important application of k𝑘k-clique counting is its use as a subroutine
in computing generalizations of approximate densest subgraph.
In this paper, we study parallel algorithms for k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph, a
generalization of the densest subgraph problem
introduced by Tsourakakis 3. Tsourakakis presents
a sequential 1/k1𝑘1/k-approximation algorithm based on iteratively
peeling the vertex with minimum k𝑘k-clique-count, and a parallel
1/(k​(1+ϵ))1𝑘1italic-ϵ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation algorithm based on a parallel
densest subgraph
algorithm of Bahmani et al. .
Sun et al. 2 give additional approximation algorithms that converge to produce
the exact solution over further iterations; these algorithms are more sophisticated and demonstrate
the tradeoff between running times and relative errors.
Recently, Fang et al. 1 propose algorithms for finding
the largest (j,Ψ)𝑗Ψ(j,\Psi)-core of a graph, or the largest subgraph
such that all vertices have at least j𝑗j subgraphs ΨΨ\Psi incident on
them.
They propose an algorithm for ΨΨ\Psi being a k𝑘k-clique that peels vertices with larger clique counts first and show
that their algorithm gives a 1/k1𝑘1/k-approximation to the k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph.
